description: From Middle English scaloun (“shallot”), from Anglo-Norman scalun (variant of Old French eschaloigne), from a Proto-Romance derivation of Vulgar Latin *escalonia, from Latin Ascalonius (in caepa (“onion”) Ascalonius, "shallot"), from Ascalo (“Ascalon”), from Ancient Greek Ἀσκάλων (Askálōn, “Ascalon, an ancient port city in the Levant”), borrowed from Biblical Hebrew אַשְׁקְלוֹן‎ (ʾašqəlôn).

entries.meaning: (now chiefly US, Ireland) A spring onion, Allium fistulosum.
(now chiefly US, Ireland) Any of various similar members of the genus Allium.
Any onion that lacks a fully developed bulb.
